Grids

Throughout this article, we'll build on the pieces you'll put together to create the columns classes used in your grids.

General Usage

A basic grid is setup by first creating a wrapping element with class row. Next, your column classes will then get used on the elements immediately within. Each column must have the class col followed by a class to determine its width and responsive breakpoint like col-md-6, for example.

Below is a basic example of a single row of three, equal-width columns, utilizing the 12-column grid system.

Column #1

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Column #2

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Column #3

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.


	

		
Column #1

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

	

	

		
Column #2

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

	

	

		
Column #3

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

For multiple rows of columns, the row class will clear the previous set.

Column #1

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Column #2

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Column #3

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Column #5

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum vulputate dignissim. Integer suscipit lacinia fringilla.

Column #6

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum vulputate dignissim. Integer suscipit lacinia fringilla.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

	

	

		
Column #2

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Responsiveness

When setting up any grid, it's important to decide what viewport you want those columns to collapse at (i.e. stack). To do this, you'll pick either xs, sm, md, or lg, to use within your grid classes.

.col-xs-* Classes containing xs will collapse and begin to stack when viewport is less than 576px. This will generally include smaller mobile devices.
.col-xs-pull-*
.col-xs-push-*
.col-xs-height
.col-sm-* Classes containing sm will collapse and begin to stack when viewport is less than 768px. This will generally include slightly larger mobile devices (or those in the landscape orientation) and smaller mobile devices.
.col-sm-pull-*
.col-sm-push-*
.col-sm-height
.col-md-* Classes containing md will collapse and begin to stack when viewport is less than 992px. This will generally include tablets (in portrait orientation) and any mobile device smaller than that.
.col-md-pull-*
.col-md-push-*
.col-md-height
.col-lg-* Classes containing lg will collapse and begin to stack when viewport is less than 1200px. This will generally include smaller desktop computers, and all tablets and mobile devices.
.col-lg-pull-*
.col-lg-push-*
.col-lg-height

Column Widths

Something fairly unique to Front Street is that we provide a 10-column grid system that can be used throughout your website in conjunction with the standard 12-column grid system. Our goal with this is to give you more flexbility in your column widths.

12-Column Grid

When grouping classes in a 12-column grid system, you want to make sure the integers all add up to 12. Below are some basic examples, but there are many other combinations you could come up with.

.col-*-2
.col-*-2
.col-*-2
.col-*-2
.col-*-2
.col-*-2

2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 = 12

.col-*-3
.col-*-3
.col-*-3
.col-*-3

3 + 3 + 3 + 3 = 12

.col-*-4
.col-*-4
.col-*-4

4 + 4 + 4 = 12

.col-*-6
.col-*-6

6 + 6 = 12

.col-*-4
.col-*-8

4 + 8 = 12

.col-*-6
.col-*-2
.col-*-2
.col-*-2

6 + 2 + 2 + 2 = 12

Note: In the above examples, all asterixis (*) would need to be replaced with a responsive breakpoint — xs, sm, md, or lg.

10-Column Grid

In most cases, you'll probably be utilizing the 12-column grid; however, one really common dilemma the 10-column grid solves is when you need five equal-width columns, which is not possible in a 12-column grid.

To separate this 10-column grid system, the column integers used in the classes are formatted like 010, 020, 030, 040, etc. However, conceptually everything is still the same; you'll want the integers to add up to 10. Below are a few examples.

.col-*-020
.col-*-020
.col-*-020
.col-*-020
.col-*-020

2 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 = 10

.col-*-010
.col-*-020
.col-*-070

2 + 2 + 7 = 10

.col-*-060
.col-*-040

6 + 4 = 10

Note: In the above examples, all asterixis (*) would need to be replaced with a responsive breakpoint — xs, sm, md, or lg.

Column Width Overview

Combining everything from above, here's an overview of all the possible column width classes. In picking your column classes you generally want to make sure all columns of a row add up to 100% and that they use the same responsive breakpoint.

Fraction Percentage Collapse @576px Collapse @767px Collapse @991px Collapse @1199px
1/12 8.33% .col-xs-1 .col-sm-1 .col-md-1 .col-lg-1
1/10 10% .col-xs-010 .col-sm-010 .col-md-010 .col-lg-010
1/6 16.66% .col-xs-2 .col-sm-2 .col-md-2 .col-lg-2
1/5 20% .col-xs-020 .col-sm-020 .col-md-020 .col-lg-020
1/4 25% .col-xs-3 .col-sm-3 .col-md-3 .col-lg-3
3/10 30% .col-xs-030 .col-sm-030 .col-md-030 .col-lg-030
1/3 33.33% .col-xs-4 .col-sm-4 .col-md-4 .col-lg-4
2/5 40% .col-xs-040 .col-sm-040 .col-md-040 .col-lg-040
5/12 41.66% .col-xs-5 .col-sm-5 .col-md-5 .col-lg-5
1/2 50% .col-xs-6 .col-sm-6 .col-md-6 .col-lg-6
7/12 58.33% .col-xs-7 .col-sm-7 .col-md-7 .col-lg-7
3/5 60% .col-xs-060 .col-sm-060 .col-md-060 .col-lg-060
2/3 66.66% .col-xs-8 .col-sm-8 .col-md-8 .col-lg-8
7/10 70% .col-xs-070 .col-sm-070 .col-md-070 .col-lg-070
3/4 75% .col-xs-9 .col-sm-9 .col-md-9 .col-lg-9
4/5 80% .col-xs-080 .col-sm-080 .col-md-080 .col-lg-080
5/6 83.33% .col-xs-10 .col-sm-10 .col-md-10 .col-lg-10
9/10 90% .col-xs-090 .col-sm-090 .col-md-090 .col-lg-090
11/12 91.66% .col-xs-11 .col-sm-11 .col-md-11 .col-lg-11
10/10 100% .col-xs-0100/td> .col-sm-0100/td> .col-md-0100/td> .col-lg-0100/td>
12/12 100% .col-xs-12 .col-sm-12 .col-md-12 .col-lg-12

Columns With Backgrounds

If you're giving entire columns background colors, you can utilize the class has-bg on the columns to make them look a little nicer. You can also utilize the classes row-flush-start and row-flush-end on the rows to make sure thse background columns to hang outside of the container. — This is probably a bit confusing; so let's work through this with some eaxmples.

The Problem

Consider the following example. — We're adding classes from the color library to give columns in a grid some background colors, but we are not using our helping classes.

Column #1

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Column #2

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Column #3

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.


	

		
Column #1

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

	

	

		
Column #2

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

	

	

		
Column #3

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

The Solution

You can see from the above example, that things are not quite looking right. There are two issues that stick out.

  1. Column Padding: Because a column now has a background color that's different from its container, it needs a little more room to breathe. So use class has-bg to add some extra padding.
  2. Column Overhang: And because the first and last columns now have a background color different from their container, they appear to hang outside of that container. So on our wrapping row, we can add class row-flush-start to fix the first column and row-flush-end to fix the last column.

And so here's an example of the same setup, with adding our helper classes to the rows and columns.

Column #1

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Column #2

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Column #3

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.


	

		
Column #1

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

	

	

		
Column #2

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

	

	

		
Column #3

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Can I mix and match? — Sure! Not every column in a row needs a background color. Below is an example where we just want the right column to have a background color. So only the right column will need the has-bg helper class. And since we now only need to worry about the last column hanging outside the container, we only need to add the class row-flush-end to our row.

Column #1

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Mauris tempus convallis lectus, placerat hendrerit ligula auctor id. Donec sodales ultrices leo, vel tempor libero. Donec maximus faucibus scelerisque.

Column #2

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.


	

		
Column #1

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

		
Mauris tempus convallis lectus, placerat hendrerit ligula auctor id. Donec sodales ultrices leo, vel tempor libero. Donec maximus faucibus scelerisque.

	

	

		
Column #2

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

Equal-Height Columns

When you start getting into more complicated setups with background colors being added to columns, being the perfectionist that you are, you may find yourself wanting those columns to be the same height, no matter the content within.

The Problem

Consider the following example. — We've got two columns with background colors applied, which have different amounts of content.

Column #1

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Praesent scelerisque arcu et accumsan pulvinar. Quisque gravida quam a est consequat, non pulvinar ante dictum.

Etiam et metus non nunc tincidunt dignissim. Vivamus non quam in felis vestibulum elementum placerat a nulla. In sapien ante, posuere id facilisis ut, molestie vitae dui. Pellentesque ac diam sed lectus convallis tincidunt. Vestibulum risus neque, commodo quis maximus vel.

Nulla tristique purus mi, faucibus interdum felis varius in. Etiam consectetur, leo ac imperdiet interdum, libero enim viverra orci.

Column #2

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.


	

		
Column #1

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Praesent scelerisque arcu et accumsan pulvinar. Quisque gravida quam a est consequat, non pulvinar ante dictum.

		
Etiam et metus non nunc tincidunt dignissim. Vivamus non quam in felis vestibulum elementum placerat a nulla. In sapien ante, posuere id facilisis ut, molestie vitae dui. Pellentesque ac diam sed lectus convallis tincidunt. Vestibulum risus neque, commodo quis maximus vel.

		
Nulla tristique purus mi, faucibus interdum felis varius in. Etiam consectetur, leo ac imperdiet interdum, libero enim viverra orci.

	

	

		
Column #2

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.

The Solution

Now the above example doesn't look terrible, but often in a scenario like this, it might look nicer if the columns were the same height. To accomplish this, we need to add helper classes to the wrapping row and inner columns.

  1. Row: To the row, we'll add a class row-*-height, and in place of the asterix, we'll use the matching responsive breakpoint used in the columns.
  2. Columns: To the columns, we'll add a class col-*-height, and again in place of the asterix, we'll use the matching responsive breakpoint.
Column #1

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Praesent scelerisque arcu et accumsan pulvinar. Quisque gravida quam a est consequat, non pulvinar ante dictum.

Etiam et metus non nunc tincidunt dignissim. Vivamus non quam in felis vestibulum elementum placerat a nulla. In sapien ante, posuere id facilisis ut, molestie vitae dui. Pellentesque ac diam sed lectus convallis tincidunt. Vestibulum risus neque, commodo quis maximus vel.

Nulla tristique purus mi, faucibus interdum felis varius in. Etiam consectetur, leo ac imperdiet interdum, libero enim viverra orci.

Column #2

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum.


	

		
Column #1

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Praesent scelerisque arcu et accumsan pulvinar. Quisque gravida quam a est consequat, non pulvinar ante dictum.

		
Etiam et metus non nunc tincidunt dignissim. Vivamus non quam in felis vestibulum elementum placerat a nulla. In sapien ante, posuere id facilisis ut, molestie vitae dui. Pellentesque ac diam sed lectus convallis tincidunt. Vestibulum risus neque, commodo quis maximus vel.

		
Nulla tristique purus mi, faucibus interdum felis varius in. Etiam consectetur, leo ac imperdiet interdum, libero enim viverra orci.

Column Ordering

By adding push and pull column classes you can shift them from their original position. The push classes will push columns to the right, while pull classes will pull columns to the left. This can be really useful, for example, when you want columns to display in a different order when stacked on mobile, than when displayed on desktops.

Consider the following example. — We've got two columns, each with the class col-md-6, which float them and sets them to 50% width. Next, on the first column we add the class col-md-push-6, which will then push it over to the right by 50%. And finally, we add class col-md-pull-6 to the last column to pull it to the left by 50%. The final result is that we've swapped the order of the two columns on desktops, but when displayed on tablets and mobile devices, they'll display in the natural order.

Column #1

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum vulputate dignissim. Integer suscipit lacinia fringilla.

Column #2

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum vulputate dignissim. Integer suscipit lacinia fringilla.


	

		
Column #1

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum vulputate dignissim. Integer suscipit lacinia fringilla.

	

	

		
Column #2

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum vulputate dignissim. Integer suscipit lacinia fringilla.

A really common dilemma this helps to solve is with setting up the primary sidebar layout of your website. — Let's say you have a sidebar positioned to the left of your content. When your columns stack on mobile, you'd want your site's primary content to display before the sidebar, right? So in thie scenario, you'd need to setup the natural order with content first and sidebar second, but then you'd add push and pull classes to rearrange the display order on desktops.

Primary Content

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum vulputate dignissim. Integer suscipit lacinia fringilla.

Left Sidebar

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.


	

		
Primary Content

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Aliquam fermentum vulputate dignissim. Integer suscipit lacinia fringilla.

	

	

		
Left Sidebar

		
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

By looking at the code for the above example, you can see it starts to get a little more complicated than our first example because both columns are not equal in width. The primary content column is 8/12 wide and the sidebar column is 4/12. This means that we must push the primary content over to the right the distance of the sidebar column, and pull the sidebar column over to the left the distance of the primary content column.

Now, in combining everything from above, here's an overview of all the possible column ordering classes.

Column Offsetting

Move columns inward using .col-*-offset-* classes. These classes increase the left margin of a column by specified columns. For example, adding the class col-md-offset-4 to a .col-md-4 element moves it over four columns.

.col-*-4
.col-*-4.col-*-offset-4
.col-*-5
.col-*-5.col-*-offset-2
.col-*-4.col-*-offset-2
.col-*-4
.col-*-6.col-*-offset-3
.col-*-040
.col-*-040.col-*-offset-020

Now, in combining everything from above, here's an overview of all the possible column offset classes.

Offset Distance Collapse @576px Collapse @767px Collapse @991px Collapse @1199px
1/12 8.33% .col-xs-offset-1 .col-sm-offset-1 .col-md-offset-1 .col-lg-offset-1
